segments.text: We are given three Java programs that are to be executed in sequence.

segments.text: The output of the first becomes the input of the second, and the output of the second becomes the input of the third.

However, note the following:
- The first program (atcoder_ABC109_B) reads an integer N and then N strings. It checks:

For each string (from the second onward), the first character must match the last character of the previous string. It outputs "Yes" if both conditions hold, otherwise "No".

segments.label: mental_execution

However, the first program outputs either "Yes" or "No". So the second program would take that as input. Example: 
      Input to second program: "Yes" -> then it will output the next character of the first character of "Yes", which is 'Y' -> next is 'Z'. But wait: the program does `s.charAt(0) + 1` and then prints as a char. So for 'Y' (ASCII 89) we get 90 which is 'Z'.

We must take the non-space last character. But we are using `len_trim` to get the last non-space character. So that's correct. Therefore, the program:

      program combined
          implicit none
          integer :: n, i, j, length
          character(len=100) :: words(100)   ! up to 100 words, each up to 100 characters
          character(len=1) :: last_char, c1, c2
          logical :: valid
          character(len=3) :: ans1   ! "Yes" or "No"

          read(*,*) n
          do i = 1, n
              read(*,*) words(i)
          end do

          ! If n==0
          if (n == 0) then
              valid = .true.
          else
              ! Initialize for the first word
              length = len_trim(words(1)) if (length == 0) then
                  valid = .false.
              else
                  last_char = words(1)(length:length)
                  valid = .true.
              end if

              ! If we have more than one word, loop from the second to the last. if (n > 1 .and. valid) then
                  do i = 2, n
                      ! Check for duplicates: in words(1:i-1) do j = 1, i-1
                          if (words(i) == words(j)) then
                              valid = .false. exit
                          end if
                      end do
                      if (.not. valid) exit

                      ! Check chain condition: the first character of the current word must equal last_char
                      if (words(i)(1:1) /= last_char) then
                          valid = .false. exit
                      end if

                      ! Update last_char for the current word
                      length = len_trim(words(i)) if (length == 0) then
                          valid = .false. exit
                      end if
                      last_char = words(i)(length:length)
                  end do
              end if
          end if

          if (valid) then
              ans1 = "Yes"
          else
              ans1 = "No"

segments.text:
because `map.get(i).substring(0,1)` would throw an exception if the word is empty. So we assume non-empty words. If we get an empty word, we set valid to false and break. Therefore, the final Fortran program:

      program combined
          implicit none
          integer :: n, i, j, length
          character(len=100) :: words(100)   ! maximum 100 words, each 100 characters
          character(len=1) :: last_char, c1, c2
          logical :: valid
          character(len=3) :: ans1

          ! Read n and the words
          read(*,*) n do i = 1, n
              read(*,*) words(i)
          end do

          ! Handle n=0 separately: valid = true
          if (n == 0) then
              valid = .true.
          else
              ! Process the first word
              length = len_trim(words(1)) if (length == 0) then
                  valid = .false.
              else
                  last_char = words(1)(length:length)
                  valid = .true.
              end if

              ! Process the rest of the words if there are more and if still valid
              if (valid .and. n > 1) then
                  do i = 2, n
                      ! Check for duplicates in the previous words
                      do j = 1, i-1
                          if (words(i) == words(j)) then
                              valid = .false.
segments.label: bug_fixing

segments.text:
exit
                          end if
                      end do
                      if (.not. valid) exit   ! break the outer loop

                      ! Check the chain condition: the first character of the current word must match last_char
                      if (words(i)(1:1) /= last_char) then
                          valid = .false. exit
                      end if

                      ! Update last_char to the last character of the current word
                      length = len_trim(words(i)) if (length == 0) then
                          valid = .false. exit
                      end if
                      last_char = words(i)(length:length)
                  end do
              end if
          end if

          if (valid) then
              ans1 = "Yes"
          else
              ans1 = "No"
          end if

          c1 = ans1(1:1)
          c2 = char(ichar(c1) + 1)
          write(*, '(a)') c2

      end program combined

  However, what if the word has leading spaces? The read(*,*) will skip leading spaces. So they are stored without leading spaces.

  So we are safe.

  But note: the chain condition: we compare the last character of the previous word. We must take the non-space last character. But we are using `len_trim` to get the last non-space character. So that's correct.

  Therefore, the program:

      program combined
          implicit none
          integer :: n, i, j, length
          character(len=100) :: words(100)   ! up to 100 words, each up to 100 characters
          character(len=1) :: last_char, c1, c2
          logical :: valid
          character(len=3) :: ans1   ! "Yes" or "No"

          read(*,*) n
          do i = 1, n
              read(*,*) words(i)
          end do

          ! If n==0
          if (n == 0) then
              valid = .true.
          else
              ! Initialize for the first word
              length = len_trim(words(1))
              if (length == 0) then
                  valid = .false.
              else
                  last_char = words(1)(length:length)
                  valid = .true.
              end if

              ! If we have more than one word, loop from the second to the last.
              if (n > 1 .and. valid) then
                  do i = 2, n
                      ! Check for duplicates: in words(1:i-1)
                      do j = 1, i-1
                          if (words(i) == words(j)) then
                              valid = .false.
                              exit
                          end if
                      end do
                      if (.not. valid) exit

                      ! Check chain condition: the first character of the current word must equal last_char
                      if (words(i)(1:1) /= last_char) then
                          valid = .false.
                          exit
                      end if

                      ! Update last_char for the current word
                      length = len_trim(words(i))
                      if (length == 0) then
                          valid = .false.
                          exit
                      end if
                      last_char = words(i)(length:length)
                  end do
              end if
          end if

          if (valid) then
              ans1 = "Yes"
          else
              ans1 = "No"
          end if

          ! Second step: take the first character of ans1
          c1 = ans1(1:1)
          c2 = char(ichar(c1) + 1)

          ! Third step: output the character and a newline
          write(*, '(a)') c2

      end program combined

But note: what if n=1? Then the loop for i=2 to n doesn't run. So we set valid to true (if the first word is non-empty) and then set ans1 to "Yes".

  Then we output the next character of 'Y' -> 'Z'. So output 'Z'.

  Example: input 
        1
        a
    -> valid: true -> ans1="Yes", then output 'Z'

  But the original chain: 
        First program: outputs "Yes" (with newline)
        Second program: reads "Yes", then outputs 'Y'+1 -> 'Z' (without newline)
        Third program: reads "Z" (without newline) and outputs "Z" and then a newline.

  So our output is 'Z' and a newline.

  Therefore, it matches.

  Another example: 
        Input:
            2
            apple
            error

        Conditions: 
            Distinct? yes.
            Last of "apple" is 'e', first of "error" is 'e' -> valid.

        Then ans1="Yes", then output 'Z'.

  But wait: what if the first word is "Yes"? Then we output 'Z'? but the chain would output 'Z'? Yes.

  But what if the first program outputs "No", then the output is 'O'.

  However, what if the first word is "No"? Then the chain:

        First program: 
            words: "No" (one word) -> valid: true -> outputs "Yes"? no: wait, n=1 -> valid=true -> "Yes".

        But if the input is:

            1
            No

        Then the first program: 
            distinct: yes (only one word).
            chain condition: none (only one word) -> valid -> output "Yes".

        Then the second program: outputs 'Z'.

        Therefore, the word "No" in the input does not cause the first program to output "No". Only if the conditions fail.

  So our program is correct.

  However, note: the first program in Java breaks the loop as soon as it finds a duplicate or chain break. We break similarly.

  We'll run the example from the problem: 
        3
        apple
        letter
        robot

        Conditions: 
            Distinct: yes.
            Chain: 
                apple -> last char 'e'
                letter -> first char 'l' -> fails.

        So valid becomes false at i=2.

        Then ans1="No", then output 'O'.

  Therefore, the program is as above.

  But note: what if there is an empty word? We check for length==0 and set valid to false.

  We assume the input words are non-empty? The problem doesn't say, but the Java program would crash if a word is empty? because `map.get(i).substring(0,1)` would throw an exception if the word is empty. So we assume non-empty words.

  If we get an empty word, we set valid to false and break.

  Therefore, the final Fortran program:

      program combined
          implicit none
          integer :: n, i, j, length
          character(len=100) :: words(100)   ! maximum 100 words, each 100 characters
          character(len=1) :: last_char, c1, c2
          logical :: valid
          character(len=3) :: ans1

          ! Read n and the words
          read(*,*) n
          do i = 1, n
              read(*,*) words(i)
          end do

          ! Handle n=0 separately: valid = true
          if (n == 0) then
              valid = .true.
          else
              ! Process the first word
              length = len_trim(words(1))
              if (length == 0) then
                  valid = .false.
              else
                  last_char = words(1)(length:length)
                  valid = .true.
              end if

              ! Process the rest of the words if there are more and if still valid
              if (valid .and. n > 1) then
                  do i = 2, n
                      ! Check for duplicates in the previous words
                      do j = 1, i-1
                          if (words(i) == words(j)) then
                              valid = .false.
                              exit
                          end if
                      end do
                      if (.not. valid) exit   ! break the outer loop

                      ! Check the chain condition: the first character of the current word must match last_char
                      if (words(i)(1:1) /= last_char) then
                          valid = .false.
                          exit
                      end if

                      ! Update last_char to the last character of the current word
                      length = len_trim(words(i))
                      if (length == 0) then
                          valid = .false.
                          exit
                      end if
                      last_char = words(i)(length:length)
                  end do
              end if
          end if

          if (valid) then
              ans1 = "Yes"
          else
              ans1 = "No"
          end if

          c1 = ans1(1:1)
          c2 = char(ichar(c1) + 1)
          write(*, '(a)') c2

      end program combined
